newsitem.title: USA: Judge won't block debut of AMD chip.
newsitem.headline: Judge won't block debut of AMD chip.

text.p: A federal judge Tuesday declined Intel Corp's request for a restraining order that would have blocked Advance Micro Devices Corp's promotional materials introducing the AMD K6 computer chip.

In a ruling after an emergency hearing, Judge Joseph Longobardi of the U.S. District Court of Delaware said that based on the limited record, Intel failed to show a likelihood of success on the merits of its trademark infringement case.
The ruling enables Advanced Micro Devices to proceed with the introduction of the new computer chip, which is compatible with Intel's MMX multimedia technology, on April 2, 1997.
In his decision, Longobardi said Advanced Micro had made a strong case that the MMX created a "new genus" of product.

Moreover, Advanced Micro had produced substantial evidence, including surveys and media articles, indicating that the public considers the MMX a type of product rather than a brand associated only with Intel, the judge ruled.
A preliminary injunction hearing is set for April 28 and Longobardi indicated the evidence developed by that time could yield a different result.
In asking for a restraining order, Intel wanted Advanced Micro Devices promotional materials to say the AMD K6 was not an "MMX processor", but an "MMX compatible processor."
Intel also wanted Advanced Micro to acknowledge that MMX was a product of Intel.
